title: How to Make Warm Drinks for the Holidays

steps.headline: Enjoy a classic hot toddy if you like bourbon, honey, and lemon.
steps.description: For each mug, heat up ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of water, then stir in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of bourbon, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey, and 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of lemon juice. Gently stir the contents until the honey has completely dissolved, and enjoy! For an elevated experience, try adding a cinnamon stick to each mug to infuse the toddy with spice, or you could even add a few slices of orange to each mug for a stronger citrus flavor. Many people enjoy making their hot toddies with tea, like chai or chamomile. To do this, just brew the tea in the ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of hot water and follow the rest of the instructions.

steps.headline: Make mulled wine for a spice-infused beverage to enjoy on cold nights.
steps.description: Pour a bottle of red wine (Cabernet Sauvignon works well), 4 cups (950 mL) of apple cider, ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of honey, and the juice of 1 orange into a saucepan. Add 4 cloves, 3 star anise, 2 cinnamon sticks, and the zest of 1 orange. Bring the mixture to a boil and then reduce the heat to a simmer for 10 minutes. Once it’s done simmering, distribute the drink amongst mugs and enjoy! For a pretty presentation, add an orange-peel twist to each mug.

steps.headline: Heat up a mug of mead if you like a sweet, thick, rich beverage.
steps.description: If you’re not making mead yourself, you can buy different varieties online, from breweries or wineries, or sometimes even from grocery stores. After you choose a bottle, simply pour the contents into a saucepan and heat it through completely. You could also add a few cinnamon sticks to the mixture to infuse it with some extra spice. The overwhelming flavor of mead is honey, though depending on what brand you buy, you can get meads that are more or less sweet. Most people buy mead already made, though you can make it yourself. It takes 3 to 6 months for it to be ready, though, so to enjoy mead during the holidays, it’s best to buy it from the store.

steps.headline: Simmer some spiced and spiked hot chocolate for a decadent treat.
steps.description: To make a single mug of this drink, you’ll need 1 cup (240 mL) of milk, 2 ounces (57 g) of bittersweet or semisweet dark chocolate, 1 cinnamon stick, 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of honey, 1/2 teaspoon (2 grams) of brown sugar, ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of vanilla extract, and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of rum. Put everything except the vanilla and rum into a small saucepan and heat the mixture until it’s simmering. Whisk in the vanilla and rum, then pour the drink into a mug and enjoy. Feel free to add more or less sweetener or alcohol to the drink depending on your personal preferences. Add a small pinch of cayenne and chili powder to give your drink a spicy kick.

steps.headline: Add some liquor to your java for a delectable, sweet Irish coffee.
steps.description: For 1 cup (240 mL) of coffee, add 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of whiskey and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of simple syrup. Add cream if you like a milkier coffee, top the drink with whipped cream, and sprinkle on a dash of nutmeg or cinnamon for the perfect afternoon pick-me-up. There are a lot of ways you can modify an Irish coffee: try substituting Kahlúa, brandy, crème de cacao, or other liqueurs for whiskey, or use a flavored creamer instead of simple syrup to sweeten your drink.

steps.headline: Keep warm with a hot White Russian, made with Kahlúa and vodka.
steps.description: In a saucepan, heat up 2.5 cups (590 mL) of coffee, ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of heavy cream, ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of Kahlúa, and ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of vodka. Simmer the drink for 3 to 4 minutes. Divide the liquid between 4 mugs, and top each hot White Russian with whipped cream. If you don’t have Kahlúa, use another liqueur that is coffee-flavored for similar results. Add more or less Kahlúa and vodka to your batch of drinks depending on your taste preferences.

steps.headline: Simmer a batch of creamy hot chocolate for you and your guests.
steps.description: Pull out your crockpot or a deep dutch oven to make a big batch of homemade hot chocolate. Mix together 1.5 cups (260 grams) of semi-sweet chocolate chips, 1/4 cup (25 grams) of cocoa powder, 1/2 cup (52 grams) of sugar, 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract, 1 cup (240 mL) of heavy cream, and 6 cups (1,400 mL) of whole milk. Turn the heat on low and stir the hot chocolate occasionally to help everything melt together. Let the mixture heat up for at least 2 hours before you serve it. Make a hot-chocolate bar by providing mini-marshmallows, cinnamon, peppermint sticks, sprinkles, and other fun toppings. The whole milk makes the hot chocolate creamier, but feel free to swap it out for a non-dairy option.

steps.headline: Brew some homemade chai for a sweet, spicy drink that’ll warm you up.
steps.description: Simmer ⁄4 cup (180 mL) of water, 2 to 4 smashed cardamom pods, 1 to 2 slices of ginger, 1 cinnamon stick, and 1 star anise in a saucepan for 3 to 4 minutes. Then add ⁄4 cup (180 mL) of milk and 1.5 teaspoons (1 gram) of loose black tea leaves, turn off the heat, and steep the tea for 2 to 3 minutes. Strain the mix through a sieve into a mug, and add honey or sugar to sweeten your drink. If you don’t want to make your own chai mix at home, buy a pre-made mix from the store. All you need to do is heat up milk or water, stir in the powder, and enjoy. You could also steep a mug of chai tea using a tea bag and then add cream and sugar to it.

steps.headline: Enjoy a pumpkin-spice latte if you like the flavors of fall.
steps.description: Heat up 1 cup (240 mL) of milk, 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of pumpkin puree, 1 tablespoon (12 grams) of sugar, 1/2 teaspoon (1 gram) of pumpkin pie spice, and ⁄4 teaspoon (1.2 mL) of vanilla extract in a small saucepan for 3 to 4 minutes. Take the pan off of the heat and whisk it for 30 to 60 seconds or until it gets a little foamy. Pour the milk mixture into a mug with ⁄4 to ⁄2 cup (59 to 118 mL) of espresso or really strong coffee. Top the drink with whipped cream and a dash of pumpkin pie spice. Use non-dairy milk if you’re lactose-free, and adjust the amount of sugar for your tastes.

steps.headline: Whip up a “Golden Milk” turmeric latte full of antioxidants and spice.
steps.description: Make a mug for you and a friend by whisking together 1 cup (240 mL) of milk, 1 cinnamon stick, 1/2 teaspoon (1 gram) of turmeric, ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) piece of ginger, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of coconut oil, 1/4 teaspoon (.5 grams) of black pepper, and 1/8 teaspoon (.25 grams) of cinnamon. Add 1 cup (240 mL) of water to the mixture and then simmer everything together in a saucepan for 8 to 10 minutes. Sieve the mixture into 2 mugs, and enjoy! Turmeric has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant characteristics, which makes it a great winter-time drink to help boost your immune system. You can also use fresh turmeric—just substitute a 1 inch (2.5 cm) piece of peeled and sliced turmeric for the dried version.

steps.headline: Enjoy wassail for a bright, sweet, citrus-based drink.
steps.description: Use your crockpot to prepare a big batch of wassail the next time you have a holiday gathering. Just mix together ⁄2 gallon (1.9 L) of apple cider, 2 cups (470 mL) of orange juice, ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of lemon juice, 12 cloves, 4 cinnamon sticks, 1 teaspoon (1.5 grams) of ground ginger, and 1 teaspoon (2.5 grams) of ground nutmeg. Let the wassail heat up and simmer for about 6 hours before you distribute it between mugs. For an extra special touch, add apple and orange slices to each mug. If you’d like to add alcohol to your drink, pour 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of brandy to your mug before pouring in the wassail.

steps.headline: Make mulled cranberry-apple cider to enjoy the sweet flavors of fall fruit.
steps.description: Put 4 cups (950 mL) of cranberry juice, 4 cups (950 mL) of apple cider, the peel from 1 orange, a 1 inch (2.5 cm) piece of ginger, 2 cinnamon sticks, 4 allspice berries, and 4 cloves into a large stockpot. Bring the mixture to a boil, and then reduce the heat and let the cider simmer for about 30 minutes. Sieve the mixture over mugs, garnish with fresh cranberries and orange slices, and enjoy! If you want a less-sweet drink, use unsweetened cider or juice.

steps.headline: Heat up a ginger-honey-lemon tonic to soothe sore throats.
steps.description: Put 1 cup (240 mL) of water, 1 inch (2.5 cm) of peeled and chopped ginger, 1/2 a lemon, and 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of honey into a small saucepan. Simmer it over low heat for 3 to 4 minutes, strain the liquid into a mug, and let your body feel warmed and soothed by the healing mix of ginger, lemon, and honey. Add more honey if you’d prefer your drink a little sweeter.
